title: 107_s1733
content: The Act titled "Name Matching for Enforcement and Security Act of 2001" establishes an interoperable law enforcement and intelligence data system with name matching capacity and training. The Act requires the development of a unified electronic data system by key government agencies to access relevant information for visa issuance and alien admissibility. The Act mandates a unified electronic data system for accessing information from law enforcement and intelligence databases to determine visa issuance and alien admissibility. The system must have name search capacity and linguistic sensitivity. The unified electronic data system required by the Act must have the capacity to match names across different databases, be linguistically sensitive, provide user support, involve private sector firms in development, use commercially available platforms, and be adjusted based on experience. The unified electronic database required by the Act must match names across databases, provide user support, involve private sector firms, use commercially available platforms, and be adjusted based on experience and technological advancements. The unified electronic database must be searchable using linguistically sensitive algorithms that account for variations in name formats and transliterations within a particular language. Linguistically sensitive algorithms must be developed for at least 4 high-priority languages, incorporating advanced research methods. The unified electronic data system must incorporate advanced linguistic, mathematical, statistical, and anthropological research methods. Linguistically sensitive algorithms for at least 4 high-priority languages are required. Adequate user support with easily accessible authoritative information must be provided. The unified electronic data system must provide easily accessed information about names in different languages and a means for communication with experts. Interim reports are required starting within 6 months. The unified electronic data system must provide information on names in different languages and a means to communicate with experts. Interim reports are required every 6 months. The Secretary of State, Attorney General, Secretary of the Treasury, Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, and Director of Central Intelligence must submit reports every 6 months to Congress on the implementation progress of the requirements. The Director of Central Intelligence must complete a survey within 60 days of the Act's enactment. The Director of Central Intelligence must complete a survey within 60 days of the Act's enactment and issue guidelines within 120 days. The Director of Intelligence must issue a report and guidelines as required by the Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1998. Authorization of appropriations is also provided. The Director of Intelligence must issue guidelines as required by the Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1998. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the implementation of the data system, with consultation required from various government officials. In the development and implementation of the data system, government officials must consult with relevant agencies and utilize established technology standards. The data system developed under this subsection must adhere to technology standards established by the United States law enforcement agencies and intelligence community. Information in the system should be easily accessible to Foreign Service officers responsible for visa issuance. The America by Providing Appropriate Tools Required to Intercept and Obstruct Terrorism Act of 2001 allows access to information in the data system for Foreign Service officers issuing visas and Federal agents determining alien admissibility. Procedures are in place to restrict access to intelligence information in the data system. The America by Providing Appropriate Tools Required to Intercept and Obstruct Terrorism Act of 2001 allows access to intelligence information in the data system for Foreign Service officers issuing visas and Federal agents determining alien admissibility. Procedures are in place to restrict access to this information for certain government officials.
